texts.shortText: An uncommon, but very distinctive species. Column cream to peach coloured with longitudinal rows of round purple spots (which are in fact batteries of stinging cells). Oral disc marked with vivid scarlet lines that radiate from the mouth to surround bases of the 48 short, stubby, white tentacles. Violet spot at each end of mouth.
Column diameter up to about 30 mm. When open can reach 50 mm across, including tentacles.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Columbine on west coast to about St Lucia in KwaZulu-Natal.

Easily recognized by virtue of its unique and distinctive colour pattern. Uncommon and usually found singly in sandy sites at or below low tide level. Has been observed greatly extending column and reaching over to consume food items on adjacent rock surface. Nothing further known about biology.
Prey unknown, but almost all anemones are unselective predators feeding on a wide variety of invertebrate taxa.
No details known, but most anemones can both reproduce sexually by releasing sperm and eggs into the water to merge and form plankton larvae, and by division of the adult.

Unlikely to be confused with any other regional anemones especially due to bright radiating red stripes on oral disc. Most similar to Dwarf spotted anemone (Anthostella sp.), which is also cream and has purple spots on column, but that species is much smaller, has purple-tipped tentacles and a plain oral disc.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 26).

Laird, MC (2013). Taxonomy, systematics and biodiversity of South African Actiniaria and Corallimorpharia. PhD Thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.
